lines.text: Shakespeare.
Longfellow. What goes up the chimney?
Santa Claus.
[Last lines]
That Laurel is the dumbest thing I ever saw.
The other one is too.
You're absolutely right, Bert. Neither one of them can see any further than the end of their nose.
[Ollie and Bert walk off the pier into the bay. Fade out]
What would you like Bubbles?
Now, don't rush me, lover. I think I'll have a nice Welsh Rarebit.
One Welsh Rarebit.
With cheese.
With cheese.
[Double-take stare at Stan]
Garcon? Garcon?
What do you mean Garcon? Grogan's the name. What'll you have?
Why, I'd like a nice, large, cold flagon of beer.
What's yours?
Bring me two nice, clean straws that haven't been used.

[comes back to the table with beer and straws]
That'll be a quarter.
A quarter? What for?
Ten cents for the beer and fifteen cents for the straws.

[hands Hardy a bill]
Here, have yourselves a fling.
A dollar? We can't do much flinging on a dollar.

[At Denker's Beer Garden]
Joe, who are these men?
When they were here before, they called themselves Mr. Laurel and Mr. Hardy.

[Slaps the table]
That's all I want to know!
[to Ollie]
Pay the check and let's get outta here.
Yes, pay it! We've been waiting two hours for you to bail us out. Bye-bye, baby face!
So, you went to a Punch and Judy show, huh!

[Stops the desert cart]
Pardon me.
[to Laurel]
Hey you, give me a hand.
[They each pick up a side of a giant birthday cake]
One, two, three.
[... and drop it on Hardy's head]
Happy Birthday, to you.
This isn't his birthday?
Never the less - Many Happy Returns. Come on, Betty, this is final!
[Storms off with Betty Laurel]
What did you want to go help her for?
Well I didn't know what she was going to do.
That's right, you wouldn't.
I think I'll have...
I know what you two guys are gonna have...
[walks off]
That's an awfully fresh waiter.
[Grogan returns and places a beer between Stan and Ollie. The throws two spoons and two straws on the table]
Stan took me to see and Punch and Judy show; I haven't seen one of those since I was a kid.
Why would they feel like that? Everybody has a black sheep in their closet.
Did you see what I saw?
Certainly, You know who they are? They're our twin brothers, Stan and Ollie
What are they doing here?
I don't know.
Shakespeare.
Longfellow.
Needles.
Pins.
We'll see you before you go.
Oh, lover!
[Goodbye kiss]
Come in, Mrs. Avaquist.
It wasn't Mrs.Twiddlepass.
Not Twiddlepass, Addlequist, eh, Ataquist, eh, never mind who it was, who was it?
Shakespeare
Long - Not now!
What's in the package, Cappy?
None of your business what's in it! Go on, get outta here. And don't call me Cappy!
And No Monkey Tricks!
Well, here's another nice mess you've gotten me into!
Hey, Finn! Are you coming back?
I wouldn't say yes and I wouldn't say no. Oh, and if I see Alice and Lily, I'll give 'em your love. Maybe I'll give 'em a kiss for you!
Shakespeare.
Longfellow.
What goes up the chimney?
Smoke.

[to Ollie]
Say, listen big boy, I don't think much of your taste. Ditching us for a couple of old frumps like these!
I beg your pardon! Do you know who you're talking to?
Ah, sit down old lady, before you fall apart.
[Sits down on Ollie's lap]
Now listen, cutie, I don't think that was very nice of you to walk out and leave us sitting here.

[Stands up]
I beg your pardon, madame, but just what do you mean?
What are you looking so innocent about?
I'm not so innocent.
You bet you're not! And if you're as guilty, as I think you are, you ought to be ashamed of yourself!
The last time I saw them they had no clothes on.
They had no clothes on? Who is this man?
I don't know, Mommy, he's an absolute stranger to us, isn't he?
He certainly is! Who am I - eh, you?
But, Momma, let me explain.
Don't ever speak to me again - you overstuffed Casanova!
Do you realize what you've done?
I don't care what I've done. Serves you right for not introducing me. Besides, they weren't so hot anyway. Where did you pick them up? Did you win them on a punch bowl?
I'm going to teach them a lesson.
How do you mean?
We are going to stay out all night! And we are not going home until they come to us and apologize!
That's a good idea. We'll give them enough rope so we can hang ourselves.
Hello, buddies. What's the trouble now?
Oh, we just had a little argument with the wives.
Yeah, you see, they don't understand us. So we're going to teach them a lesson. Aren't we Ollie?
Yes and we're going to stay out - all night!
Yeah, till nine o'clock.
You know that's funny. I'm in the doghouse too!
Well, we're all in the same boat!
All for one and one for all!
All!
Shakespeare.
Longfellow.
George Washington.
What goes down the flue?
A good slug of liquor!
Right!
Well, what do you think we better do?
That's entirely up to you. You thought of a way to get us into this mess. Now, think of a way to get us out of it.

[Stranded in a hotel with no clothes, Laurel suggests they dress up like the "fellas that look like Eskimos" in "Singapore" - using bed quilts and towels as their set of clothes]
That sounds screwy to me. But, any old port in a storm.
It might be a good idea.
You've gotta be right once in your life!
Stan and Oliver have been arrested. And they haven't any clothes on! And they've taken them to the police station. Oh!
Oh, this is a fine state of affairs!
What'd he say?
I don't know?
Don't you speak Arabic?
Oh, no sir. We're a couple of Singapore Eskimos.
Funny looking dames, aren't they?
I don't know. I kinda like that big, fat blonde.
The little one wasn't so bad.
They're cute.
Hey, listen, sailor. Lay off of the blonde! I saw her first!
What's the matter? We can explain everything?
You can't explain those two old cronies!
They're not old cronies. They're a couple of old welfare workers.
Well, sit down and have a drink.
We will as soon as we get rid of these two old battle-axes.
Yeah, we'll soon get rid of them.
[the two old battle-axes walk up behind them]
Is that so!
Oh, we want you to meet the two girls we met this afternoon.
Yeah, Lily and Alice.
I know all about them - you ungrateful hound!
You double-crossing swab, give me that ring.
Are you trying to frighten me? Go ahead, little boy, and peddle your fish.
Ya, ya know the trouble with him? He's drunk.
Before, it was two to one. Now, it's three to two. That makes it even.
You must be balmy. We haven't seen you since...
Balmy, am I! At 'em boys!
You're sure lookin' good, Stanley. But, how you have altered.
You've altered too, but, you haven't changed a bit.
